description: Now that the State of Illinois has entered Phase 3 of the pandemic response, Orion is taking steps to reopen. On Monday, June 1, Western District Library has opened the drive-up book drop in the alley. All items have a due date of June 26.
text:
Now that the State of Illinois has entered Phase 3 of the pandemic response,
Orion is taking steps to reopen.

On Monday, June 1, Western District Library has opened the drive-up book drop
in the alley. Patrons wishing to return books and DVDs should use the
appropriate slot. All items have a due date of June 26.

Anyone with items that may be damaged in the book drop should keep them until
the library is able to have patrons return them in person. These items include
magazines, puzzles and hot spots.

Curbside pick-up will begin Wednesday, June 10. More details will be released
later.

Patrons can visit <https://omnilibraries.overdrive.com/> to access e-books and
audiobooks with their library cards. Anyone who lives in the area but does not
have a library card can use a mobile number to sign up to use the site.

Overseeing the changes is the new library director, Michelle Bailey, whose
first day was June 1.

At an emergency meeting of the Orion village board on Tuesday, May 26, Village
President Jim Cooper said Orion would defer to Gov. J.B. Pritzker's
restrictions on the use of parks.

Trustee Mike Dunlap, chairman of the parks committee, announced the partial
reopening of Love and Central parks at the regular village board meeting on
Monday, June 1.

Basketball and tennis courts are open, but playground equipment, bathrooms and
drinking fountains are still closed, Dunlap said.

The village is allowing ball teams to practice with a maximum of 10 players
and one adult coach and no spectators, he said.

Scrimmages will be allowed, but not competitive games, Cooper said. Coaches
will have to work out practice schedules themselves. Village Clerk Lori
Sampson will not schedule the use of diamonds.

Cooper said on May 26 that he had discussed opening village hall with Village
Clerk Lori Sampson, and they had decided there was no immediate need to open
the building to the public. He affirmed the decision on June 1.

The Village of Orion joined Andover, Cambridge, Geneseo, Kewanee, Galva,
Colona, Atkinson, Annawan and Woodhull to prepare a plan for reopening
businesses during Phase 3. Also part of the planning were Hammond-Henry
Hospital, the Henry & Stark County Health Department and the Geneseo Chamber
of Commerce.

To find the plan, "Forward Together: Reopening & Recovery Toolkit for
Business," visit
[https:www.cityofgeneseo.com/covid-19-updates/](http://https:www.cityofgeneseo.com/covid-19-updates/).

Click on "Henry County Toolkit" for the Phase 3 plan, and on "Road to
Recovery: Restore Henry County Municipalities" for an overview of all five
phases.

"Henry County Toolkit" can be saved as a PDF and downloaded.

title: Orion cautiously reopening
html:
Now that the State of Illinois has entered Phase 3 of the pandemic response, Orion is taking steps to reopen.

On Monday, June 1, Western District Library has opened the drive-up book drop in the alley. Patrons wishing to return books and DVDs should use the appropriate slot. All items have a due date of June 26.

Anyone with items that may be damaged in the book drop should keep them until the library is able to have patrons return them in person. These items include magazines, puzzles and hot spots.

Curbside pick-up will begin Wednesday, June 10. More details will be released later.

Patrons can visit https://omnilibraries.overdrive.com/ to access e-books and audiobooks with their library cards. Anyone who lives in the area but does not have a library card can use a mobile number to sign up to use the site.

Overseeing the changes is the new library director, Michelle Bailey, whose first day was June 1.

At an emergency meeting of the Orion village board on Tuesday, May 26, Village President Jim Cooper said Orion would defer to Gov. J.B. Pritzker's restrictions on the use of parks.

Trustee Mike Dunlap, chairman of the parks committee, announced the partial reopening of Love and Central parks at the regular village board meeting on Monday, June 1.

Basketball and tennis courts are open, but playground equipment, bathrooms and drinking fountains are still closed, Dunlap said.

The village is allowing ball teams to practice with a maximum of 10 players and one adult coach and no spectators, he said.

Scrimmages will be allowed, but not competitive games, Cooper said. Coaches will have to work out practice schedules themselves. Village Clerk Lori Sampson will not schedule the use of diamonds.

Cooper said on May 26 that he had discussed opening village hall with Village Clerk Lori Sampson, and they had decided there was no immediate need to open the building to the public. He affirmed the decision on June 1.

The Village of Orion joined Andover, Cambridge, Geneseo, Kewanee, Galva, Colona, Atkinson, Annawan and Woodhull to prepare a plan for reopening businesses during Phase 3. Also part of the planning were Hammond-Henry Hospital, the Henry & Stark County Health Department and the Geneseo Chamber of Commerce.

To find the plan, "Forward Together: Reopening & Recovery Toolkit for Business," visit https:www.cityofgeneseo.com/covid-19-updates/.

Click on "Henry County Toolkit" for the Phase 3 plan, and on "Road to Recovery: Restore Henry County Municipalities" for an overview of all five phases.

"Henry County Toolkit" can be saved as a PDF and downloaded.
